lines.text: Corrina, can I talk to you for a minute? Look, whatever you may believe in is fine for you, okay? Your heaven is fine for you, but Molly's mother was an atheist and so am I, and I don't want you telling her that her mother is somewhere she isn't.
Yes, Mr. Singer. I'll just continue to tell Molly her mother is in the bathtub.
Grandpa, can you hear me?
[nods]
Make Daddy marry Corrina, okay?
[nods]

[to Molly]
I'm sorry I'm late, I'm sorry I'm late, I'll never be late again but you don't know what happened to me. A herd of elephants stopped in the middle of the road for a drink of water and I didn't know what to do! So I... are you stuck on me with Elmer's glue? Yes you are, I guess I'm just going to have to carry you.
Do you taste like chocolate?
I don't know, do you taste like vanilla?
Is Tater Tot Mr. Potato Head's son?

[laughing hysterically, holding a mug to his ear]
That's the funniest thing you ever told me in your whole life!
Why don't I just talk to Mrs. Singer?
Oh, well... she's... she's... she's in the bathtub right now.
This is my favorite record.
Really? Mine, too.
You know, Billie Holliday does a better version.
No-one's better than Louie.
Have you ever had a block?
All my life.
Molly, why did you take my cigarettes? Answer me.
Corrina's husband went out for a carton of cigarettes and died. They all die. The TV said it.
Manny, listen to me. A fish and a bird can fall in love, but where do they build their home?
I won the spelling bee today.
You did? Corrina, did you hear that?
I heard it, now let's go eat, I'm starved.
What was the word?
...Vacuum.
Why don't we vacuum ourselves out the door?
How do you spell vacuum?
...H-O-O-V-E-R.

[to Molly]
Do you want the pecan waffles with lots of syrup and butter or would you rather have the slim starter with the cottage cheese, the hard boiled egg and the tomato?
Darling, if it's a choice between those delicious waffles and that STUPID egg, for God's sake, pat your little nose.
She should've cleaned up before we got here.
That is a novel idea.
[to Molly]
You're the short, silent type aren't you? -I could tell.

[on phone]
Hi, daddy.
Molly?
You recognized my voice!
What do you think you're doing?
Well, I-I can't sleep.

[towards her bedroom door]
Goodnight, Molly!

One of the last things my wife said to me was, "Don't forget to pick up some almonds on the way home." She said she had a coupon for roasted... But I was in a hurry and I didn't wait until she found it.
I don't think she was angry, Manny. I think she understood. Now, do you wanna know the last thing I said to my husband?
What?
Slow down.
Huh?
Slow... down.
[Manny laughs]
She's been playing that little piano ditty all morning. Do you think you could get her to cut it out?
Her mother was teaching her that.
I see you've got a list started here. Is this groceries?
That's my wife's handwriting. I haven't been able to erase it yet.
Oh, well, I'll just add onto it.
You know what I've discovered about your daddy? He likes to eat cookies in bed. Could you tuck that sheet in... just there?
Corrina... this is where my mommy sleeps.
You're right. Your mommy used to sleep here.
When is she coming back?
Well, Molly... she's not coming back. When you die, the angels take you up to heaven to be with God.
Then I want to die, too.
My daddy doesn't think she's in heaven.

Well, that's probably just because your daddy is so jealous of the angels. He's so jealous, he can't even stand to think about those angels who get to play with your mommy all day long. And he's hurting just like you're hurting, and you're going to hurt for a long time. Every day it'll get a little better, but you'll always miss your mommy, and that's okay.
Where are my cigarettes?
I just put a fresh carton in there!
Well, I don't see any.
Well, I can't even offer you one of mine since you've taken to smoking those, too.
What's that supposed to mean?
It means that if you're going to smoke my cigarettes, I'd appreciate you telling me.
Fine. If you're gonna smoke *my* cigarettes, I'd appreciate you telling me.
Fine.
What you've got to say to yourself is, "I am Molly Singer, and there's nobody in the world better than me." Go on, say it while you walk.
I am Molly Singer, and there's nobody in the world better than me.
Chin up, up! You're too young to have two!
But I'm just so? I'm just so?
So mad. You're just so mad. And it's okay to be mad, Molly.
Molly, I'm mad, too! I'm mad at Mommy for leaving us. I'm mad because I want to talk to Mommy every day, and I can't. I'm mad because I want to bring Mommy back to you, and I can't do that, either.
I'm mad because she didn't even say goodbye.
I'm mad about that, too.
I'm mad because she made you mad! I'm mad! She should've said goodbye!
How dare you keep her out of school, Corrina! How dare you!
Manny, she was not ready to go back to school, yet.
You're not her mother, Corrina! That's not your decision!
What is this, high school?
What? Now look. This is nice, huh?
Oh no. Now that's cute.
You can't fit in that.
I can still fit in somethin' like that.
You cannot. Have you seen what's behind you recently? Let me turn to the maternity page.

[hits the car against a pole]
I was just testing the brakes and it'll do your heart good to know they work.
[Cleaning together]
Isn't it fun to make things shiny?
Well I think the thrill for me is gone...

[on phone]
Operator? We're having trouble on our line; can you dial that number again?
